Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Current processors employ aggressive prediction mechanisms to improve
performance and reduce power. To design effective optimizations, it is
increasingly important to understand and quantify a program's dynamic
behavior. However, today, most of these optimizations rely on
heuristics and are fairly ad-hoc. After some patterns are observed, a
hardware decision is made and the design space of the hardware
optimization is explored through simulation to determine the best
performing configuration. However, because the design is targeted for
observed and/or anticipated patterns, some dynamic behavior is not
captured and remains undetected.

This project develops a framework for quantitatively analyzing a
program's behavior in terms of regularities and patterns to provide
insights into the design of next-generation hardware prediction
mechanisms. Inspired by DNA discovery tools, the research adopts
algorithms used in string processing, compression and bioinformatics,
in order to summarize applications' dynamic data reference and branch
outcome behaviors. The findings from the methods and tools developed
in this project will have a big impact on the design and efficiency of future
hardware components. The PI will collaborate with industry partners to further
increase the broader impact. The research will engage graduate and
undergraduate students and promote the participation of
underrepresented groups.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Current processors employ aggressive prediction mechanisms to alleaviate the performance bottlenecks caused by the high-latencies of off-chip memory accesses and minimize performance penalty of control-flow changes. To design effective optimizations, it is neccessary to understand and quantify a program's dynamic behavior. This project has developed a tool called PatternFinder for quantitatively analyzing a program's behavior in terms of regularities and patterns to provide insights into the design of next-generation hardware prediction mechanisms. The PatternFinder's design is inspired by DNA discovery tools and adapts algorithms used in string processing, compression and bioinformatics, in order to summarize applications? dynamic data reference and branch outcome behaviors.

The findings from the methods and tools developed in this project will potentially have a big impact on the design of future hardware prediction mechanisms, such as data prefetchers and branch predictors. PatternFinder has been instrumental to evaluate and summarize memory access and branch outcome patterns. We used our findings to design prefetchers and pre-execution units to alleviate both memory and branch bottlenecks.

The funding for this project has allowed four graduate working on this project to develop new skills in computer systems performance analysis and computer architecture, and to develop new tools for the broader research community. In addition, the students have done summer internships and secured full time positionsthat are very closely related to this project. As a result, this project has achieved the objectives of providing training for a new generation of computer engineers while also enhancing PI's collaborations with industry.

The results of this project has been disseminated through publications at conferences and through the project webpage.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2019
Modified by: Resit Sendag

PatternFinder has been instrumental to evaluate and summarize memory access and branch outcome patterns. We used our findings to design prefetchers and pre-execution units to alleviate both memory and branch bottlenecks.
